issue.title: Adds CBOM for liboqs
issue.body:
Adds code to generate and validate a CBOM json file, and the CBOM itself.

- CBOM generator: update_cbom.py
- CBOM: cbom.json
- CBOM schema validation: validate_cbom.sh
- CBOM schema validation added to github actions

Adds oqs_alg to docs yml. This allows to connect oqs algorithms to the OIDs defined in the openssl-project so the OIDs can be recorded in the CBOM.

Also corrects a few common crypto sources in Kyber and Dilithium docs (wan't updated after migrating to liboqs common crypto).

Fixes #1336 

<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider), [OQS-OpenSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl), [OQS-BoringSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl), and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

issue.title: Doxygen uses hardcoded output directory
issue.body:
When running `ninja gen_docs`, `doxygen` always generate the docs on top of the `src` directory instead of using the build directory passed to `cmake`. This happens because of this line in Doxyfile

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/2e42595804242d1e24e04f0f770a348c0c22313b/docs/.Doxyfile#L61

And it will fail to create the directory `docs` if `build` doesn't exist already.

comment.body: I don't understand what you mean by "generate the docs on top of the src directory" -- I see them being generated in build/docs.  That being said, I agree that we have hardcoded the directory in the Doxyfile to build/docs rather than whatever directory cmake was run in; I don't know how to fix that because the .Doxyfile is not generated by CMake.

issue.title: Update PQClean commit in `copy_from_upstream.yml`
issue.body: Once https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/issues/1317 is done, we should also update the PQClean `git_commit` hash in [copy_from_upstream.yml](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/main/scripts/copy_from_upstream/copy_from_upstream.yml#L6) to at least [b0fc0c098c7930e04931071a46cc7d520a1f8d1b](https://github.com/PQClean/PQClean/commit/b0fc0c098c7930e04931071a46cc7d520a1f8d1b) or more recent so we don't continue pulling removed algorithms.

comment.body: Looks like we can do this now, @xvzcf
CI should pass when #1350 has been merged.

issue.title: How to encrypt message with the symetric key of kem
issue.body:
How to encrypt message with the symetric key of kem when i generated a shared secret? 
eg: https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-rust/blob/main/oqs/src/lib.rs#L31, how can i use `b_kem_ss` to encrypt message?

comment.body:
This crate offers only public-key cryptography primitives (specifically for key exchange and digital signatures): you seem to be looking for symmetric key encryption. You could for example look at one of the Rust-Crypto crates, such as https://docs.rs/aes-gcm/latest/aes_gcm/.

On a related note, a brief warning: if you're playing with cryptography, for fun or to learn stuff: cool! By all means, go for it and have fun. Just maybe add some warnings in the README and other docs that it's just an experiment and not meant for production use. "Rolling your own crypto" is completely fine, if it's for fun and learning. ðŸ˜„ 

But if you're trying to build something that is actually going to be published and/or used: cryptography can be very, very tricky and nuanced, and tiny mistakes can be very painful. Going for something off-the-shelf is usually safer. Otherwise, you need to get some expert help.

issue.title: Doxygen uses hardcoded output directory
issue.body:
When running `ninja gen_docs`, `doxygen` always generate the docs on top of the `src` directory instead of using the build directory passed to `cmake`. This happens because of this line in Doxyfile

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/2e42595804242d1e24e04f0f770a348c0c22313b/docs/.Doxyfile#L61

And it will fail to create the directory `docs` if `build` doesn't exist already.

comment.body:
I meant `src`/build/docs with `src` being the path of the source code. Probably this is not relevant for people just downloading the source code and compiling locally, but it can be an issue for packagers. I actually noticed this while creating a [package for Arch Linux](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/liboqs). The "standard" way of dealing with cmake packages in Arch (and I guess other distros) when building in a clean chroot environment is to have the `src` and build in the same directory, not build inside `src` (see how I pass `-C` and `-S` to `cmake` in the `build()` function.

Isn't it possible to delete that line from the Doxyfile and handle that in the `CMakeLists.txt`?

issue.title: llvm15 update
issue.body:
This follows https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/ci-containers/pull/65 and unblocks CI failures.

Suggested to merge after #1351

comment.body: Could you fix the conflict and then we can merge it in?

comment.body:
> > @bhess Is this ready to merge?
> 
> Ready from my side. I pushed an update today with changes to reflect the comments in the PR.
> 
> Creating the cbom is now integrated in the copy_from_upstream script (it updates the docs and the cbom).
> 
> Some CI seem to fail, I assume this will fix itself with #1350

Thanks. I merged #1350 and have rebased this PR based on #1350, we'll wait for the tests to pass then we can merge.

issue.title: Algorithm enablement
issue.body:
Following up on https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/issues/1245#issuecomment-1338878620 this is to propose implementing a `cmake` build option labelled "OQS_ALGS_ENABLED" with the following possible values and effects:
- STD: Enabling Kyber512,768,1024 (no 90s), Dilithium2,3,5 (no AES), SPHINCS+ (not robust), Falcon
- NIST_R4: Enabling All algs explicitly listed for round 4 of the NIST competition
- EXPERIMENTAL: Enabling all algs not removed from liboqs; this would also activate for example Dilithium5AES or "robust" SPHINCS+ (and possibly NTRUPrime algs along the lines of [this discussion](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/issues/1245#issuecomment-1346632256)).

Proposed default value: "STD" (also to be activated if "OQS_ALGS_ENABLED" is not explicitly set).

Comments/alternative proposals welcome before implementing as described.

comment.body: In terms of dealing with the downstream build problems that came when I prematurely merged #1333, what about changing it so that that the default is ALL, so that all the downstream tests will see an unchanged list of algorithms.  Expert users can use the added liboqs CMake option to build a subset of the algorithms. At this point in time they'd also need to regenerate code in the downstream projects if they wanted to build against that subset of algorithms, but perhaps someday we'd find the time to do something smoother.
